title: ECOG Performance Status (WHO Scale) – Expanded
summary: Comprehensive guide to the ECOG Performance Status scale, including clinical applications, limitations, and future directions in oncology practice.
author: Oncology Practice Team

content.text: The ECOG Performance Status (PS) scale is a standardized tool developed by the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group to assess a cancer patient's functional capacity. It ranges from 0 (fully active) to 5 (deceased) and plays a central role in oncologic decision-making. The ECOG scale is not only used to evaluate treatment fitness but also to predict prognosis, assess clinical trial eligibility, and guide palliative care needs. Despite its simplicity, its subjectivity and lack of granularity require clinicians to contextualize its use within broader clinical assessments.

rows: Fully active. No limitations in daily life. Can perform work and strenuous physical activity.
Restricted in physically strenuous activity. Ambulatory and able to do light/sedentary work.
Ambulatory and capable of all self-care, but unable to work. Up and about >50% of waking hours.
Limited self-care ability. Confined to bed/chair >50% of waking hours.
Completely disabled. No self-care. Totally confined to bed or chair.

items: Survival Correlation: A strong inverse relationship between ECOG score and overall survival (OS) and progression-free survival (PFS).
Treatment Response: High ECOG (0-1) correlates with better response rates and treatment tolerance.

rows: Full-intensity systemic therapy; eligible for most clinical trials.
Dose-reduced or single-agent therapy; careful toxicity monitoring.
Focus on palliation, symptom relief; generally not for systemic therapy.

items: Used to select chemotherapy regimens and determine candidacy for immunotherapy and biologics.
- Immunotherapy trials: Usually restricted to ECOG 0-1.
- Targeted therapy: Some agents are tolerated even in ECOG 2-3 patients.
Higher ECOG correlates with increased perioperative complications.
Insensitive to short-term fluctuations (e.g., temporary infections, fatigue).
Use in combination with other tools:
- Functional tests: Timed Up & Go, grip strength, ADLs/IADLs.
ECOG integrated into Palliative Performance Scales (PPS).

content.text: AMBOSS Note: Tools such as Karnofsky, PPS, and ECOG are among the core functional assessments in palliative medicine ([source](https://www.amboss.com/us/knowledge/overview-of-palliative-medicine?utm_medium=chatgpt-plugin&utm_source=chatgpt)).

items: Reimbursement and treatment authorization may require documentation of ECOG.
Health technology assessments (e.g., NICE, PBS) may use ECOG thresholds to justify:
Digital ECOG Tracking: Wearable devices for step counts, sleep, and activity tracking.
AI-Enhanced Scoring: Algorithms to estimate PS from electronic health record (EHR) data.
Dynamic ECOG Models: Time-series approaches capturing performance trajectory, not static value.
Molecular Correlation: Integration with sarcopenia imaging, cachexia indices, and metabolic signatures.

content.text: The ECOG Performance Status scale is more than a clinical shorthand—it's a tool that encapsulates a patient's physical resilience, therapeutic window, and prognostic outlook. As oncology care becomes more personalized, ECOG remains a touchstone for aligning treatment intensity with patient capacity. Augmented by multidisciplinary input and evolving technology, it continues to serve as a foundation for functional oncology in both high- and low-resource settings.

When documenting ECOG status, always include specific examples of functional limitations (e.g., 'ECOG 2 - patient can dress and feed independently but becomes short of breath after walking 20 meters') to improve reliability across providers.
